abstract.p: The production of this forecast is supported by the Institute's Corporate Members: Bank of England, HM Treasury, Mizuho Research Institute Ltd, the Office for National Statistics, Santander (UK) plc and by the members of the NiGEM users group.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The UK economy remains in a relatively weak condition. Output has been broadly flat for the past 2½ years, unemployment remains close to 8 per cent of the labour force, CPI inflation is still above target and the hoped for rebalancing of the UK economy looks to be a considerable way off, with a deficit on the balance of payments averaging 3.7 per cent of GDP in 2012. The Preliminary Estimate for GDP growth in the first quarter of this year does not change this view. Much of the attention focused on the avoidance of a ‘triple-dip’, rather than another quarter of relatively weak economic growth. Revisions to data mean that the very notion of a ‘double-dip’ rests on the most modest of declines in output (see figure 1). As we have noted many times before, obsessing about a couple of quarters where output experiences a minute fall distracts us from the clear trend: that of a stagnating economy.

caption.p: Real GDP growth (per cent per quarter)

sec.p: The absence of a sustained period of robust growth has plagued the UK economy since the end of the ‘Great Recession’ in the second quarter of 2009. Economic performance is perhaps better described as ‘stagnant’. At NIESR, we have used the term ‘depressed’ to describe an economy that has not yet recovered its pre-recession peak. Such a term is perhaps fitting for an economy that has regained only half of the drop in output of the 2008–9 recession. Recovery is defined as a period of above potential (or trend) economic growth, a necessary condition if a negative output gap is to be closed. The performance of the economy in the first quarter of this year does not suggest we have yet got to a point that can be viewed as a sustained recovery. We do expect growth of between 0.2 and 0.3 per cent per quarter through the rest of this year, leading to an overall rate of growth of 0.9 per cent for 2013.1 This forecast is broadly unchanged from that published in our February Review. This is true for subsequent years, where we expect economic growth of 1½ per cent per annum in 2014, accelerating to just over 2 per cent per annum for the period 2015–17.

We estimate that the potential rate of growth is around 2 per cent per annum. Mechanically, growth in the period 2015–17 would be consistent with ‘recovery’ – just. It is over this period of time when we expect the unemployment rate to follow a path that has a clear downward trajectory, consistent with the pick-up in demand absorbing the significant spare capacity in the economy. If we define a rebalancing of the economy as a narrowing of the deficit on the balance of payments (an increasing proportion of domestic investment funded through domestic saving) then the recovery we currently expect is much less ‘balanced’ than previously expected. The current account deficit is expected to narrow from an average of 3.7 per cent of GDP in 2012, but to remain around 2½ per cent of national income over the forecast horizon – a position little improved on the years before the crisis.

In the Budget published in March 2013, the government has announced increases in capital spending, but the relatively modest £3 billion per annum increase is not planned to be implemented until 2015–16, by which time we expect the economy to be recovering. These additional increases in capital are funded through tax increases from a change in the tax treatment of contributions to final salary pension schemes. Given the difference in fiscal multipliers between spending and taxation, such a policy discussion is likely to have a positive effect on economic growth, but the net effect will be miniscule. The fiscal stance further out has been improved via additional reductions to future current expenditures. Current Resource Departmental Expenditure Limits have been reduced by an additional cumulative £18.5 billion over the period 2015–16 to 2017–18. These are important as they set the spending envelope for the next Comprehensive Spending Review period, details of which are likely to be announced this June. By 2015–16, the government's primary budget balance (public sector net borrowing less government interest payments) is expected to be in surplus.

The government's primary target of its Fiscal Mandate is for the cyclically-adjusted current budget to be in surplus in five years time (currently 2017–18). The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) is tasked with evaluating whether this has more than a 50 per cent chance of happening. With an unadjusted current budget of around ½ per cent of GDP in 2017–18, and the persistent presence of a negative output gap, we think there is considerably more than a 50 per cent chance that the cyclically adjusted budget balance will have moved into surplus; the medium-term policy goal of stabilising the public finances will have been achieved.

However, it remains our view that fiscal policy can be used to support the economy in the near term through fiscal instruments that support the government's other long-term policy goal of raising the potential rate of growth. As Besley et al. (2013, this Review) note, investment in education, innovation and infrastructure is essential for future economic growth. With 10-year government bonds attracting yields of less than 2 per cent, the government can finance additional investment in much needed infrastructure at little cost. With an economy in such a depressed state the fiscal multipliers are likely to be far higher than in normal times (Holland, 2012). However, it does appear unlikely that the government will implement any significant increases in capital spending in the near term. Focusing exclusively on the longer term, the government should use June's Comprehensive Spending Review to re-evaluate future levels of public sector investment in the economy. The question of whether net investment should be allowed to fall to under 1½ per cent of GDP should be answered.

sec.title: Monetary and financial conditions
sec.p: Yield curves have reversed their temporary increases at the start of the year. The UK yield curve has returned to about the same level as at the start of the fourth quarter of last year (figure 2). Markets currently expect Bank Rate to remain at 0.5 per cent until the summer of 2015. We broadly agree with this prognosis. There have been some notes of concern about inflation remaining above target for such a sustained period of time but, given the weak state of demand in the economy at present, it is highly unlikely that we will see a majority vote for any interest rate increases over the coming year.

caption.p: Interest rate expectations

sec.p: Inflation expectations in financial markets and on the basis of household surveys (see figure A1) appear to be contained. However, the depreciation of sterling at the start of this year drove near-term CPI inflation rates even higher, adding to the effect of the increase in tuition fees and sharp rises in domestic energy prices. These are likely to be only temporary effects on the rate of price inflation, but they follow on from a series of temporary price shocks that have all pushed the rate of inflation in one direction.

caption.p: Summary of the forecast Percentage change

fn.p: Notes: RPDI is real personal disposable income. PSNB is public sector net borrowing. PSND is public sector net debt. (a) Fiscal year, excludes the impact of financial sector interventions, but includes the flows from the Asset Purchase Facility of the Bank of England. Includes the impact of the transfer of assets and liabilities from the Royal Mail pension scheme in April 2012. (b) PSNB excluding the royal Mail pension transfer is £ 113.4 billion (7.3 per cent of GDP) in 2012–13.

sec.p: We have undertaken a counterfactual experiment using our global econometric model NiGEM to illustrate the effect on the economy had the MPC adjusted Bank Rate in order to bring the rate of CPI inflation much closer to target this year and next. We run the simulation from 2011 as the effect of monetary policy has significant lags. Financial markets are assumed to be forward looking and we expect the MPC will continue to increase interest rates over the course of 2011 and 2012 to bring the rate of inflation close to target in 2013. This leads to a jump in the exchange rate almost immediately, supporting a drop in the rate of inflation. However, with business expecting a monetary tightening to continue, business investment falls almost immediately, dragging down GDP growth by almost 1 percentage point. The economy would have been plunged back into a period of contraction, with the unemployment rate rising by around 1 percentage point. With the rate of CPI inflation dropping below target in 2014, relative to our baseline forecast, this highlights the difficulty the MPC face with respect to keeping inflation close to the 2 per cent target in the presence of a large negative output gap and a series of temporary price shocks.

Discussion is currently over whether to introduce more monetary stimulus via additional quantitative easing. It is the present policy of government that monetary policy should be used to offset any further weakness in the UK economy: the Chancellor's call for ‘monetary activism’ to be combined with fiscal responsibility. The Chancellor has announced an adjustment to the monetary policy remit. This adjustment, at least partially, just reflects the policy response of the Bank of England to the financial crisis, but it also recognises the trade-offs between inflation and economic growth. The Chancellor has asked the MPC to report on the implementation of unspecified intermediate targets for monetary policy alongside the August Inflation Report. It is unlikely that we will see much of a change in the monetary policy stance before the publication of the MPC's views on intermediate targets. But we should remember that changes to monetary policy will be largely dictated by the shape of the economy rather than by modest changes to the remit for monetary policy.

caption.p: The impact of a counterfactual monetary tightening

sec.p: The Bank of England and Treasury have announced that the Funding for Lending (FLS) scheme will be extended by a year, to January 2015. The government clearly expects the impaired state of the UK banking system to persist throughout next year, with the FLS extension an attempt to maintain lower funding costs for banks and support lending to the real economy. Unfortunately, the evidence to date suggests that while the FLS has lowered the marginal funding costs of banks, some of which has translated into lower interest rates on mortgages in particular, the actual effect on the quantity of lending appears to be somewhat limited, with aggregate net lending under the scheme falling. The extended scheme has had its incentive structure adjusted to try and support lending to SMEs. While there is evidence that SMEs face significantly enhanced credit constraints (Armstrong, et al., 2013) there is no guarantee that the FLS will directly lead to greater lending to SMEs. The Bank of England's Agents Summary of Business Conditions published in April 2013 suggests that credit conditions for SMEs have not improved.

The government has announced a major mortgage market intervention. The scheme transfers a significant proportion of the risk on mortgage lending to the taxpayer by guaranteeing the first 20 per cent of losses on any mortgage lending under the scheme. Combined with the extended FLS, this is fairly significant taxpayer support for the UK banking system. While both schemes should help to lower the marginal funding costs of UK banks, it is unclear that it will result in significant increases in lending to viable parts of the real economy. The interaction between the FLS and Help to Buy scheme could well result in the concentration of much of the benefit in the form of lower mortgage rates for existing home owners. However, there are already signs of a modest pick-up in lending to first-time buyers and at higher loan-to-value ratios before the announcement of the Help to Buy scheme. The Bank of England Credit Conditions Survey for the first quarter of this year notes the improvements. But it is unfortunate that these interventions are likely to exacerbate the affordability problems afflicting UK housing via the stimulation of house price inflation rather than improve affordability through an expansion of supply. At the same time these measures fail to address the structural problems of an impaired banking system.

sec.title: Prices and earnings
sec.p: The labour market continues to exert little inflationary pressure. The regular pay component of AWE, a measure of underlying pay pressures, has grown at or below 2 per cent per annum throughout the entirety of 2012. However, the increased demand for labour throughout 2012, even as the demand for goods and services failed to materialise, raised the rate of growth in unit labour costs; unit labour costs increased by 2.5 per cent per annum in 2012. This is the fastest rate of growth since the period of labour hoarding over the course of the Great Recession of 2008–9. Unit labour cost growth is expected to ease back sharply this year as nominal wage growth eases further. The regular pay component of Average Weekly Earnings has decelerated sharply at the start of 2013. In the three months to February, regular pay increased by just 1 per cent per annum, down from 1.9 per cent in the three months to September. The growth rate of total earnings was even more muted, as bonus pay fell.

The measure of average earnings, reported in table A5, is average wages per employee using the National Accounts definition of employee compensation. This is gross of taxes and includes the social contributions paid by employers. Consistent with developments in the AWE measures of regular and total pay, we expect subdued wage growth at the start of this year. Pay settlements data from the XpertHR pay databank suggest that pay settlements have picked up slightly the first few months of 2013, but are still consistent with muted growth in average wages. Overall, we expect compensation per employee to expand by just 1.2 per cent this year before accelerating to a more ‘normal’ rate of around 2¾–3 per cent per annum in future years. Implicit in this forecast is the assumption that productivity growth will return to rates of growth close to 2 per cent per annum for a period. In the absence of any acceleration in the rate of productivity growth it is unlikely that we will see a pick-up in nominal wage growth, and certainly not any significant increases in the rate of real consumer wages.

Government policy is expected to put little upward pressure on wage growth this year. The government has announced that the National Minimum Wage will be uprated by 1.9 per cent, to £6.31 per hour for the adult rate, in October 2013, broadly consistent with the growth of average earnings over the past few years and significantly below where we expect the rate of CPI inflation to be in the final quarter of this year (see figure 3).

caption.p: CPI fan chart (per cent per annum)

sec.p: The rate of CPI inflation averaged 2.8 per cent per annum in the first three months of 2013. Around 0.3 percentage point of this can be attributed to the increase in university tuition fees in England and Wales from £3,000 to a maximum of £9,000. Nevertheless, stripping out the effect of an increase in tuition fees still leaves the rate of CPI inflation above target for the first three months of this year. CPI inflation has now been consistently above target since December 2009. Much of the elevated rate of inflation can be attributed to a series of policy and external shocks. These include increases in the standard rate of VAT at the start of 2010 and 2011, the robust pass-through of import prices to consumer prices and a series of energy price shocks to the UK economy, notwithstanding the recent increase in tuition fees. Much is made of services inflation on the elevation of CPI inflation measures over the past few years as a clear sign of domestic inflationary pressures. However, the inclusion of domestic energy supply in the services category conflates this notion of domestic inflationary pressures.

The increase in tuition fees will keep the rate of CPI inflation elevated over a three-year period, as the first cohort moves through their three-year degree programme. Over this period we need to bear in mind the upward effect this change in higher education fees has on the profile of CPI inflation. Upward pressures form sharp rises by domestic energy suppliers and the sharp depreciation of sterling are expected to push the CPI rate of inflation back above 3 per cent temporarily. The rise in import prices is expected to keep the rate of inflation higher this year and next than previously expected. Import prices are expected to rise by 3 per cent this year, before falling modestly in 2014. CPI inflation is expected to drop just below the target rate of inflation in 2016 as the pressure from import price rises eases and the upward effect of increased tuition fees will have ceased.

There is a considerable degree of uncertainty surrounding any prediction of the future. The forecasts presented here are no exception. Figure 3 reports the 90, 85 and 80 per cent confidence intervals around our modal CPI inflation forecast. These confidence intervals are derived from our global econometric model (NiGEM). These are derived from stochastic simulations, using random draws from the past residuals on our behavioural equations. An additional benefit of stochastic simulations is that they are able to take into account the conventional policy environment, in this case the zero lower bound for nominal interest rates. The simulations highlight the significant risk that inflation will remain above target over the forecast horizon. However, they also reinforce the point that the UK and global economies continue to face deflationary headwinds, with a limited ability to respond with conventional monetary policy.

sec.title: Components of demand
sec.p: Domestic demand growth more than offset the negative contribution from net trade in 2012. It was underpinned by the contribution from consumption growth, both private and public. Consumption in the UK economy contributed 1.2 percentage points to GDP growth in 2012, the most robust contribution to GDP growth since 2007. Of course a strong contribution from relatively import intensive consumer spending is, at least partly, behind the negative contribution from net trade. This pattern of domestic demand growth, more than offsetting a negative contribution from net trade, is expected to persist through this year and next, albeit with the negative contribution from net trade considerably more muted at around −0.2 percentage point per annum.

Until a Blue Book adjustment is made to a particular calendar year, overall GDP growth is determined from the output approach to GDP measurement. In the case of the Preliminary Estimate of GDP, the decomposition of GDP is entirely output based. Output growth of 0.3 per cent per quarter at the start of this year was dominated by the contribution of the service sector. The data suggest that distribution, hotels and catering, which includes the retail sector, contributed 0.2 percentage point to GDP growth, equal to the rest of the private service sector's contribution, suggesting that consumer spending continued to expand into the first quarter of this year.

Real consumer spending is expected to contribute around ¾ percentage point to GDP growth this year and next. As figure A5 implies, much of this increase in due to population growth rather than a significant increase in the per capita consumption of UK residents. Nevertheless, the return of consumer spending growth is a necessary condition for the beginning of a sustained period of accelerating economic growth. Consumer spending growth is expected to accelerate in 2014 and 2015 as average wage growth finally outpaces the rate of price inflation. Until this happens, it is difficult to see how per capita consumer spending can pick up to a meaningful degree.

Real general government consumption increased by 2.2 per cent per annum in 2012, the most robust pace of growth since 2004. With the exception of 2011, real government consumption has expanded in every year since 1998. However, demographics are an important determinant of government consumption growth. Simplifying to consumption per capita suggests that per capita real government consumption declined by 1.2 per cent over the period 2010–11, before reversing in 2012. With the intense discussion around fiscal consolidation in the UK, these developments are perhaps surprising. There are two important reasons that explain this apparent discrepancy. Firstly, fiscal consolidation in 2010 and 2011 was dominated by tax increases and cuts to investment spending. Secondly, the measurement of government consumption volumes, and output, are such that the ‘cuts’ to the current component of Resource Departmental Expenditure Limits materialise through the price measure (see figure 4), for 64 per cent of departmental spending volumes are measures on the basis of activity: for example, the number of operations, prescriptions and pupils taught (see Pope, 2013). This dominates the estimation of volumes in the large spending departments such as health and education. Between the second quarter of 2010 and final quarter of 2012, the volume of government consumption has increased by 1.6 per cent. This is despite general government employment shrinking by 9 per cent (521 thousand). Over the same period of time the government consumption price deflator has increased by just 0.5 per cent. Overall nominal general government consumption has declined from 23.4 per cent of GDP in 2009 to 22.1 per cent of GDP in 2012. Taking on board the current spending envelope as set out by the OBR, we expect nominal government spending to have dropped to around 18½ per cent of GDP in 2017. Much of this is via a depressed rate of inflation (figure 4), but the magnitude of future general government activity is expected to be reduced by a cumulative 2¾ per cent over the next four years, or 6 per cent in per capita terms.

caption.p: General government and broad economy inflation rates (per cent per annum)

sec.p: The recent performance of the UK export sector has been poor. Exports declined by 0.2 per cent in 2012. While the growth of goods export volumes was relatively weak during 2012, overall they still managed to expand by 1.7 per cent. The overall export weakness was down to the performance of the export of services, which declined by 2.8 per cent. This service sector weakness was due to falls in the export of financial services in particular. This is probably related to the weakness in Euro Area markets as well as UK banks’ attempts to shrink the size of their balance sheets. Export performance at the start of the year also looks relatively weak. The data for services suggest little change in the value of exports. Data on the volume of goods exports suggest a decline of 0.9 per cent per quarter in the three months to February 2013. Export volumes to the EU declined by 3.1 per cent over the same period, with exports to non-EU destinations increasing by 1.3 per cent. These figures are flattered somewhat by exceptionally strong exports in December. As the data move forward to a complete calendar quarter it is likely that the rate of growth in exports to non-EU countries will be significantly closer to zero.

Export demand from the Euro Area is expected to be particularly weak this year, contributing to a further fall in UK export volumes. We expect export volumes to contract by just over 1 per cent this year. The depreciation of sterling is expected to filter through into price competitiveness gains for exporters.

However, we expect some exporters, particularly in the manufacturing sector, to absorb some of the gains in terms of widening profit margins rather than expanding market share. The net rate of return throughout 2012 was at an historically low level. Manufacturing productivity fell by 4.1 per cent in 2012, undoubtedly depressing firms’ profitability. Nevertheless, we do expect export growth to pick up significantly as growth resumes in the Euro Area. Export growth is forecast to contribute more than 1 percentage point to GDP growth, on average, over the period 2014 to 2017. Even when the Euro Area resumes provision of a significant positive contribution to world GDP growth, the structural shift in UK exports towards faster growing markets will persist. While exports to the Euro Area will increase over the medium to longer term, it is likely that we will see a continuation of the variation on the trend reported in figure A3, with exports to non-EU countries growing at a faster pace than to EU countries.

sec.title: Household sector
sec.p: Gross household financial wealth is heavily dependent on equity price developments. Equity prices have risen robustly, globally, since the second half of 2012, inflating the gross wealth positions of households. Gross household financial worth increased by 1.9 per cent and 3.1 per cent in the third and fourth quarters of 2012, respectively. Equity prices surged in the first quarter of this year. The FTSE All-Share Index increased by 8.3 per cent, recovering the nominal levels prior to the onset of the Great Recession. The increase in the gross financial asset position of households has also been supported by the inflow from a household saving ratio that averaged 7.1 per cent in 2012.

Our preferred measure of house prices is a seasonally adjusted version of the ONS mix-adjusted house price index, which is a broader measure of the housing market than either the Halifax or Nationwide house price indices. The ONS measure suggests that national house prices have increased in every quarter since the third quarter of 2011. The Halifax and Nationwide are measured at the mortgage approval stage of a house price purchase and the ONS index is measured at the mortgage completion stage. While the ONS is our preferred measure, the difference in timings means that the Halifax and Nationwide indices lead the ONS measure, providing us with useful information about the near-term developments in UK house prices. The Halifax index has reported house price inflation of growth of 1.1 per cent per annum in the first quarter of 2013, up from no growth in the fourth quarter of 2012. The Nationwide index reports a similar pattern, but with a much weaker rate of inflation: just 0.3 per cent per annum in the first quarter of this year. These data suggest that we should expect a further increase in the ONS rate of house price inflation in much of the second quarter of this year.

Overall we expect house prices to rise by around 2½ per cent in 2013. This is an upward revision on our previous forecast of just ½ per cent, published in the February 2013 Review. This is probably related to the effect of the FLS on a relatively moribund housing market. Any modest pick-up in housing transactions due to a slight easing in mortgage conditions would be expected to materialise in house price inflation. Looking further ahead we do not expect this rate of increase to be maintained. Over the period 2014–16 we expect house price inflation to fall by just 1 per cent per annum rather than the 1½ per cent per annum decline previously expected. The announcement of the extension to the FLS will likely see a continuation of the increased availability of mortgages at higher loan-to-value ratios, while maintaining interest rates at a lower rate than would otherwise be the case. The impact of the government's Help to Buy Scheme is uncertain (House of Commons Treasury Committee, 2013). There is a risk that it will translate into higher house prices than we currently expect. While this poses an upside risk to economic activity in 2014 and 2015, it is likely to come at the expense of improvements in the affordability of housing in the UK.

Our forecast for aggregate consumer spending is determined in the long run by real income growth and the real net worth of households. Underlying these is the impact of a rising population. In the short run, changes in contemporaneous real incomes drive consumption. Barrell and Davis (2007) also found a role for real net financial and real housing wealth, with the effect of real housing wealth on consumption significantly greater than that of real financial wealth. In both the long and short run, however, it is real disposable incomes that dominate consumption developments. Once we account for the increase in population, consumer spending has barely grown since 2009. This is unsurprising given that real consumer wages have fallen almost continuously since the first quarter of 2009.

Aggregate consumer spending is expected to rise by just over 1 per cent this year, after an increase of 1.2 per cent in 2012. A disproportionate share of this consumer spending growth has been on durable goods, in particular on motor vehicles. Durable goods spending surged by 10.3 per cent in 2012; the volume of spending on motor cars increased by 16 per cent. Data from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders suggest that robust growth in the private purchase of motor cars was maintained into the first quarter of this year, with year-on-year growth of 7.1 per cent in new car registrations in March 2013. The robust growth in motor car sales is likely to be due to the absence of any price inflation in 2012. Such a strong rate of growth is unlikely to persist over the forecast horizon, and we expect durable spending growth to slow to a more muted pace over the next four years. Overall consumer spending growth is expected to accelerate gradually over the next four years through a more robust increase in real disposable incomes. It is not a sudden surge in nominal wage growth that is behind this. Growth in nominal compensation per employee is expected to remain relatively stable at around 2¾–3 per cent per annum over the next five years. The moderation in consumer price inflation is expected to allow real consumer wages to rise from 2014 onwards.

sec.title: Supply conditions
sec.p: The latest employment figures suggest there was little change in employment between the three months to February 2013 and the three months to November 2012. Is this a sign that the robust labour market performance in aggregate employment figures is losing momentum? This is possible. Employment has expanded by 1.8 per cent between the third quarter of 2010 and the first quarter of 2013. In stark contrast, the economy has expanded by just 1.1 per cent.

The rate of unemployment increased from 7.8 per cent in the second half of 2012 to 7.9 per cent in the three months to February 2013. This had more to do with an inflow from inactivity into active labour market participation than population increase. The number of the working age economically inactive declined by 57,000. Women not in employment or actively seeking work who look after their family or home are classified in the official statistics as economically inactive. ONS estimates suggest that 45,000 of this group began actively to seek work in the three months to February 2013. This group numbered just over 2 million, the lowest number since records began in 1993.

It is quite possible that such developments are a response to the near continuous decline in real consumer wages since the start of 2009. As Bell and Blanchflower (2013, this Review) highlight, there has been a significant increase in the number of people employed (part-time and full-time) who would like to work more hours in their existing job. Under such circumstances it may be that additional income to maintain the standard of living for a household is only possible through both partners actively engaging with the labour market.

We expect employment to continue to rise over the course of the forecast horizon. However, over the next couple of years we do not expect the pace of net job creation to be enough to absorb the rate of increase in the labour force. If this is the case, the unemployment rate is expected to rise back above 8 per cent over the course of this year and next. As we note above, we expect real consumer wages to continue to fall this year. The demand for additional hours is likely to continue to rise under such conditions. The underemployment metric reported by Bell and Blanchflower is likely to continue to rise over the course of at least this year and possibly into 2014.

With rising employment and only a modest increase in GDP, there is little expectation of a sharp rebound in productivity growth. The level of productivity in 2007 is only expected to recover in 2015. Compared with the pre-crisis trend the discrepancy is still vast and, by implication, expected to widen further over the next few years.

Goodridge et al., (2013, this Review), suggest that the inclusion of intangible investment would raise the level of productivity in the UK by 1 per cent. In addition, the slowdown in intangibles investment since 2000 can account for some weakening in the growth of total factor productivity. Combining these two factors, they suggest, can explain almost a third of the productivity puzzle. But, as they note, this still leaves a large puzzle to solve. In June 2013, the ONS will publish the next set of Quarterly National Accounts. These will be consistent with ESA10 and thus classify R&D spending as investment rather than as an intermediate consumption by business. This will revise economic history to some degree, pushing the historical level of GDP upwards. Figure 5 reports R&D spending as a share of GDP over the period 1985 to 2011. Spending, as a proportion of GDP, is time varying, which implies that the effect on the level of GDP will not be uniform across time. Thus the inclusion of R&D spending, ceterus paribus, will affect the historical GDP growth rates.

caption.p: R&D expenditure as a per cent of GDP

sec.title: Public finances
sec.p: Since the onset of the financial crisis we have published projections for the public finances that exclude the effect of temporary financial sector interventions by the government. Even so, the public sector finance figures have become increasingly distorted by a variety of factors. In 2012–13 these include the effect of the transfer of cash from the Bank of England's Asset Purchase Facility (APF), which lower public sector net borrowing by £6.4 billion, the sale of the 4G Spectrum via auction which raised £2.3 billion, the transfer of the £2.3 billion final profit from the Special Liquidity Scheme to the Treasury and the transfer of the Royal Mail's pension fund, which lowered the borrowing requirement by an additional £28 billion. Headline borrowing, which includes the effect of these activities, is estimated to have been £86.2 billion in 2012–13, down from £120.9 billion in 2011–12. In order to understand the state of the underlying public sector net borrowing figures it is necessary to remove the distortions of the cash transfers from the APF and the transfer of the Royal Mail pension fund. Table 3 does exactly this, reporting the effect of including and excluding both the APF Royal Mail pension fund transfers on the three core public finance aggregates.

caption.p: The effect of APF flows on the fiscal forecast

td.italic: Surplus on the current budget (as a per cent of GDP)
Public sector net borrowing (as a per cent of GDP)
Public sector net debt (as a per cent of GDP)

fn.p: Notes: APF is Asset Purchase Facility; excludes the impact of the transfer of the Royal Mail pension fund in April 2012.

sec.p: The public finance projections presented in tables 3 and A8 are based on seasonally adjusted National Accounts data and therefore differ from the figures reported in the Public Finance Statistics by the ONS. The public finance statistics suggest that the underlying borrowing figure was £123.2 billion in 2012–13. In other words, in the absence of these distortions, public sector net borrowing actually rose by £2.3 billion between 2011–12 and 2012–13.

In March 2013 the Chancellor announced a broad package of changes to tax policy and spending plans over the next five years. The government has announced that the personal allowance for income tax will rise to £10,000 earlier than previously expected. This is expected to lower tax revenues by around £1 billion in 2014–15, rising to £1.2 billion by 2017–18. The Chancellor announced a £3 billion increase in capital spending from 2015–16, which is funded through changes to the tax treatment of contributions to final salary pension schemes, which amounts to an increase in the amount of tax paid on incomes, increasing revenues by over £5 billion per annum from 2016–17.

Tax revenues are endogenously determined in our global econometric model, NiGEM. They are determined by the mix of money GDP growth together with the tax policy announcements by government. We also assume that fiscal drag over the forecast horizon results in an additional upward trajectory in the income tax burden faced by households. Overall the outlook for tax aggregate tax revenues are little changed from our forecast published in the February 2013 Review. We expect tax revenues to rise from around 37¾ per cent of GDP in 2012–13 to around 38¾ per cent of GDP in 2016–17 and 2017–18.

Budget 2013 sets the overall envelope for spending for the next Comprehensive Spending Review period. We assume that the plans for current and capital Resource Departmental Expenditure Limits are broadly met over the forecast period. These include an additional reduction of £4.6 billion in current expenditure in 2015–16, £6.3 billion in 2016–17 and £7.6 billion in 2017–18. As noted above, capital expenditure has been increased by £3 billion per annum over the course of these years. The Annually Managed Expenditure (AME) component of total managed expenditure is endogenously determined in our model. The OBR have revised up their projections for AME spending over the period 2015–16 to 2017–18 by a cumulative £8.9 billion. This is almost entirely due to changes to the OBR forecast for government interest payments. In contrast our projections for AME are broadly unchanged from our February forecast. Our forecast for the evolution of the economy is broadly unchanged, as is our projection for the evolution of the government debt stock. The crucial differences that determine the divergence between our forecast for government interest payments and that of the OBR is through a ‘flatter’ yield curve than the OBR expect, as well as a significantly lower forecast for RPI inflation. The difference in RPI inflation is at least in part due to a projection for weaker house price growth than the OBR expect.

With these net reductions in total managed expenditure towards the end of the forecast period, we now expect a sharper improvement in the position of the public finances than in our February forecast. Our forecast shows the deficit on the current budget narrowing from £92 billion (6 per cent of GDP) in 2011–12 to £27 billion (1.5 per cent of GDP) in 2016–17 and just £7.5 billion (0.4 per cent of GDP) in 2017–18. In contrast, we expected a deficit of closer to 1 per cent of GDP in our February 2013 forecast. With public sector net investment 0.2 per cent of GDP higher in 2017–18 than previously projected, the improvement in public sector net borrowing is less pronounced. By 2017–18 we expect borrowing to have shrunk to £33.5 billion (1.8 per cent of GDP), in contrast to a previous forecast of 2.1 per cent of GDP.

There are upside risks to our projections for the public finances. Apart from some pick-up in output this year as the Elgin gas field in the North Sea gradually comes back on stream, our underlying assumption is of a gradual decline in output from the oil and gas extraction sector. As Oil and Gas UK (2013) highlights, investment in the oil and gas extraction sector picked up significantly in 2012, from £8.5 billion in 2011 to £11.4 billion in 2012. Investment is expected to rise even further this year. There is the upside risk that output will be higher than we currently assume, leading to stronger revenues from the oil and gas sector than currently assumed. Offsetting this is the uncertainty about the outcome of the referendum on Scottish independence to be held in 2014.

The government is likely to undertake asset sales over the course of the next five years. The magnitude of the receipts from these sales is uncertain and we have therefore not attempted to predict them. Future asset sales will not have a direct effect on the current budget deficit and public sector net borrowing, but would lower the public sector net cash requirement, reducing the flow onto the government debt stock. In the absence of further asset sales we expect the nominal value of gross government debt to peak at 97.3 per cent of GDP in 2015.

sec.title: Saving and investment
sec.p: The balance between saving and investment of each of the institutional sectors of the economy and for the nation as a whole are reported in table A8. Aside from net national saving, the reported figures are all gross of depreciation. The difference between the saving and investment for each of the institutional sectors determines the funding position of a particular sector. An excess of investment over saving is financed by net borrowing of that sector. An excess of investment over saving at the national level is funded by means of a deficit on the balance of payments.

The deficit on the balance of payments has been greater than 1 per cent of GDP since 1999. In the years directly preceding the financial crisis, the balance of payments deficit averaged 2.5 per cent of GDP. Over the course of the Great Recession the deficit narrowed to just over 1 per cent of GDP. Since then, the deficit has widened to 3.7 per cent of GDP, the largest deficit since 1989. The widening of the deficit in 2012 occurred due to a sharp drop in the net lending position of the corporate sector in turn due to a sharp reduction in corporate gross saving. Gross national saving declined to 10.7 per cent in 2012, the lowest level since records began in 1987. Depreciation in the UK is the equivalent of around 10 per cent of GDP. Adjusting for depreciation, net national saving is estimated to have dropped to zero per cent of GDP in 2012.

National saving is expected to pick up significantly over the next five years, primarily due to the reduction in the rate of government dis-saving. Gross fixed investment is expected to grow at a faster rate than economic growth from around 2014 onwards. But with only a modest increase in overall gross saving the deficit on the balance of payments is expected to narrow to around 2½ per cent of GDP.

The balance of payments is the flow onto the net asset position of the UK. The UK has been running continuous deficits on the current account resulting in an accumulation of foreign financial liabilities. Depreciation and revaluation can lead to sharp adjustments of the net asset position, which was −35 per cent of nominal GDP at the end of 2012, down from −16.9 per cent of nominal GDP at the end of 2011. Much of this was due to a fall in the stock of financial derivatives. Over the next few years the net asset position is expected to remain relatively stable.

sec.title: The medium-term
sec.p: Our view of the medium-term outlook for the UK economy is a view about the adjustment from the current disequilibrium. This is a gradual process where rates of growth in excess of the economy's potential are necessary in order to ensure that the negative output gap is closed. With rates of growth hovering just above our estimate of potential, it will take a prolonged period of time for the output gap to close. Our estimate of the long-run potential growth rate of the economy is around 2 per cent per annum. Over the medium term we expect economic growth to accelerate to around 2½ per cent per annum as the economy adjusts slowly from its current disequilibrium.

The current weak productivity performance is not expected to persist; rather, productivity growth is expected to exhibit its normal pro-cyclical properties and recover in line with the pick-up in demand. Alongside this, the labour input is expected to grow by ½ per cent per annum over the medium term. We expect the rate of unemployment to ease back to around 6½ per cent over the medium term, suggesting that the equilibrium unemployment rate has increased permanently relative to before the crisis. Monetary activism is unlikely to be able to bring the unemployment rate down further over the medium term. Government policy with regard to labour market reform is likely to be required, in particular using active labour market policy to address any pick-up in long-term unemployment as a consequence of the crisis.

Public sector net borrowing over the medium term is expected to average close to 1 per cent of GDP, implying a surplus on the government's current budget balance. Gross government debt will remain elevated over the medium term at around 86 per cent of GDP. The exact nature of the fiscal stance over the medium to long run is uncertain. As Barrell and Kirby (2010) note, a tighter long-run fiscal stance should be considered if the debt stock is to be brought down to a level that allows future governments to respond to crises as well as to be fair to future generations. This should not be taken as a view that public sector net investment should be kept as weak as is currently the case in order to ensure a tighter long-run fiscal stance. There are additional pressures on long-run government spending from the demands of an ageing population. As OBR (2012) highlights, these funding pressures depend heavily on the evolution of productivity performance in the healthcare sector. As Pope (2013) reminds us, output in healthcare and consequently productivity are difficult to measure.

The rate of inflation is expected to remain close to, but below target over the medium term. If we have significantly over-estimated the economy's potential rate of growth then it may well be that domestic pressures will push price inflation above target, or monetary policy will have to be tighter than currently expected.

fn.p: The carry-over effect from the contraction at the end of 2012 weighs on the overall economic growth rate for 2013.

Barrell R. and Davis E.P. (2007), ‘Financial liberalisation, consumption and wealth effects in 7 OECD countries’, Scottish Journal of Political Economy, 54, 2, pp. 254–67.
Barrell R. and Kirby S. (2010), ‘Medium-term prospects for the public finances’, National Institute Economic Review, 212, pp. F60–67.
Bell D.N.F. and Blanchflower D.G. (2013), ‘Underemployment in the UK revisited’, National Institute Economic Review, 224, May, pp. F8–22.
Besley T., Coelho M. and Van Reenen J. (2013), ‘Investing for prosperity: skills, infrastructure and innovation’, National Institute Economic Review, 224, May, pp. R1–13.
Goodridge P., Haskel J. and Wallis G. (2013), ‘Can intangible investment explain the UK productivity puzzle?’, National Institute Economic Review, 224, May, pp. R48–58.
Holland D. (2012), ‘Less austerity, more growth?’, NIESR Discussion Paper No. 400.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
ack.p: The forecast was completed using the latest version of the National Institute Global Econometric Model (NiGEM). Thanks to Dawn Holland for helpful comments and suggestions. Thanks to Jean MacRae for all her help. Unless otherwise stated, the source of all data reported in the figures and tables is the NiGEM database and forecast baseline.
The UK forecast was completed on 25 April 2013.

fn.p: Notes: We assume that bilateral exchange rates for the second quarter of this year are the average of the first three weeks of April. We then assume that bilateral rates remain constant for the third and fourth quarters of 2013 before moving in–line with the path implied by the backward–looking uncovered interest rate parity condition based on interest rate differentials relative to the US.
